citation.article-title: Fermentation of tartrate enantiomers by anaerobic bacteria, and description of two new species of strict anaerobes, Ruminococcus pasteurii and Ilyobacter tartaricus

p.s: Description of Ilyobacter tartaricus sp. nov.
Ilyobacter tartaricus (tar. ta'ri, cus.M.L.n, acidum tartaricum tartaric acid; tartarieus referring to tartaric acid as isolation substrate)
Short, straight rods, 1.0 x 1.2-1.2-2.5 μm in size, often in chains, surrounded by slime capsules, non-motile, Gram-negative, non-sporeforming.
Grows on L-tartrate, citrate, pyruvate, oxaloacetate, glucose, fructose, raffinose, glycerol.
Fermentation products include acetate, formate, and ethanol.

No growth on formate, acetate, lactate, methanol, ethanol, ethylene glycol, 2,3-butanediol, glycerate, malate, fumarate, glyoxylate, glycolate, mannose, maltose, lactose, sucrose, cellobiose, sorbose, rhamnose, trehalose, xylose, arabinose, peptone, yeast extract.
Grows in saltwater medium with at least 1% sodium chloride.
Oxidized sulfur compounds or nitrate not reduced.
Indole not formed, gelatin or urea not hydrolyzed.
Selective enrichment from marine sediments with L-tartrate as sole carbon and energy source.
Type strain: GraTa2, DSM 2382, deposited in Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen, Göttingen.
